title: R42134
content: Risk adjustment is the process of adjusting payments to health insurance plans based on differences in the risk characteristics of enrollees. This helps level the playing field by ensuring fair payments based on factors like gender, age, geography, and health status. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) pays private health plans under Medicare Advantage (MA or Medicare Part C) and how these payments are risk adjusted. Risk adjustment models consider factors like age, geography, health status, and family size to account for differences in expected health care spending. CMS conducts audits at the contract level, using a three-step process: sampling, medical record review, and error rate calculation/payment adjustment. These criteria include being enrolled in an MA contract in January of the payment year, continuous enrollment for 12 months, non-ESRD status, non-hospice status, full Medicare Part B coverage, and having at least one risk adjustment diagnosis. The American Academy of Actuaries expressed concerns about the audit process and the accuracy of risk adjustment models in estimating payment errors and adjusting premiums. The AAA's position is that the Medicare fee-for-service data used for risk adjustments may contain errors and the methodology was not designed to adjust premiums accurately. They are concerned about the inconsistency in applying risk adjustment factors developed with unvalidated data to MA data that is validated. This could result in premiums not reflecting the actual risk profiles of enrollees. The proposed audit process aims to apply risk adjustment factors only to validated MA data, which differs from the data used to develop the risk adjustment model. This inconsistency could lead to inadequate payments for certain conditions, creating uncertainty and potential systematic underpayment. The Health Practice Council is concerned about data inconsistency in risk adjustment for MA plans, which could lead to underpayment and payment inequities. The proposed audit process aims to address this by applying risk adjustment factors only to validated data, but uncertainty remains in estimating risk scores and plan bids. The addition of a fee-for-service adjuster to the final recovery amount may help mitigate these concerns. The Council is concerned about the modified payment methodology for MA plans not reflecting enrollees' risk profiles accurately. A fee-for-service adjuster has been added to address this issue. There are concerns about using Medicare fee-for-service data for risk adjustment coefficients and potential financial risks from RADV audits. The Secretary's approach to methodological concerns in risk adjustment implementation remains to be seen. The history of Part C risk adjustment payments for Medicare private plans involves various models to adjust for the cost of healthcare among beneficiaries. Different models have been used over the years, each increasing in complexity and explanatory power. The R2 measure is used to assess how well a model predicts individual beneficiary expenditures. The R2 measure is used to assess how well different models predict individual Medicare beneficiary expenditures. The models attempt to predict spending based on beneficiary characteristics, with the most recent model able to explain approximately 12.5% of the variation in expenditures. The Average Adjusted Per Capita Cost (AAPCC) model has an R2 of 0.0077, explaining 0.77% of variation in beneficiary expenditures. Prior models increased the explained variation, with the most recent proposed model able to explain approximately 12.5% of the variation. The demographic variables in the AAPCC model include age, sex, Medicaid enrollment, institutionalized status, and working aged status. These variables explain less than 1% of expenditure variation. The model does not account for health costs or adjust payments for enrolling. The Principal In-Patient Diagnostic Cost Group (PIP-DCG) model, implemented by CMS from 2000 to 2003, considered beneficiary health status and the worst principal inpatient diagnosis. This model explained more of the variation in Medicare expenditures compared to the AAPCC model. Starting in 2004, Medicare plan payments were adjusted by the CMS-HCC model, which incorporates information from various healthcare settings to determine payments. Starting in 2004, Medicare plan payments were adjusted by the CMS-HCC model, which considers severity of illness, accumulated effects of multiple diseases, and interactive effects. The model explains nearly 10% of expenditure variation and is updated annually to reflect changes in diagnosis codes. The CMS-HCC model, updated annually, explains nearly 10% of expenditure variation. Version 12 and Version 21 include updates to diagnosis codes and recalibration with recent data, increasing predictive power to around 12.5%. Version 21 will be implemented in 2012 for PACE plans.
